Empires & Puzzles Vander Review: 5-Star Legendary Dark Hero Strategy Guide

Vander brings a fast-paced silencing game to Empires & Puzzles. With a cyborg cowboy aesthetic and a skill that scales with Dark shields, he can be a simple sniper or a team-wrecking silencer. But do his stats hold up in the modern era? Let's find out.
Vander Review: The Cyborg Captain's Guide to Silence
Vander, The Cyborg Captain: Silence is Golden (and Purple)

Vander stormed into Empires & Puzzles in August 2024 as part of the Super Elemental Summon. A 5-star Dark Legendary hero, he brings the "Cyborg Captain" aesthetic to the battlefield, looking like he walked straight out of a space western. His primary role is damage dealing and control via Silence, operating at Fast mana speed. What makes him tick is his conditional area of effect: he starts as a sniper but can evolve into a hit-3 or even a hit-all monster depending on how purple your board is. While he doesn't offer a costume yet, his base form alone gives us plenty to talk about. He's the kind of hero who tells the enemy to "shut up" quite literally.

Vander sports a unique look that blends high-fantasy necromancy with futuristic tech. He is rocking a purple cowboy hat with a feather, a glowing mechanical arm, and grenades on his belt that look suspiciously like magic potions. The purple hue is dominant, fitting his element, and the background hints at a cosmic setting. It is a bold design choice that stands out from the usual knights and dragons. You have to admire a guy who brings grenades to a sword fight.
When we look at Vander's base stats (1114 Attack, 1100 Defense, 1854 HP) and compare them to the juggernauts released in late 2025, the gap is evident. Modern heroes like

are pushing 1300+ in Attack and Defense with HP pools well over 2200. Vander is effectively a generation behind. While his stats were impressive in mid-2024, in the current landscape, they are merely average. He won't tank hits like the newest behemoths, but his attack stat is still serviceable enough to make his special skill sting.

Gloom Grenades is a skill that rewards board manipulation. At its baseline, it deals 450% damage to a single target and silences them for 3 turns at Fast speed. This alone is a solid, if standard, sniper kitâ€”comparable to a modernized Peters or Hansel.
The magic happens with the tile conditionals:
The effect spreads to nearby enemies (Hit-3). This is the sweet spot. Hitting three enemies for 450% damage and silencing them all at Fast speed is devastating and can swing a raid instantly.

The effect hits everyone. While theoretically amazing, leaving 12 Dark tiles on the board while also charging Vander is a rare alignment of the stars. Treat this as a fun bonus rather than a reliable strategy.

Unlike some newer heroes who bypass defenses or ignore passives, Vander plays it straight: damage and silence. The Silence effect is particularly valuable in a meta filled with powerful passive abilities and healers, as it stops them cold.

Fast speed means he charges in 8 tiles. With a level 29 Mana Troop or appropriate bard/family bonuses, you can get this down to 7 tiles. This speed is crucial for a silencer, as you need to shut down threats before they fire.

With a base attack of 1114, a 450% hit deals roughly 5013 raw damage (before defense reduction). If he hits 3 targets (Condition 1), total raw output jumps to ~15,000. For comparison, modern single-target snipers often hit for 600%+, but hitting three targets at 450% is superior total damage.
3 turns of Silence is significant. In Fast wars, this can lock down an entire flank if the board cooperates.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Super Elemental family brings some interesting mechanics to the table, primarily focused on mono-color play or heavy stacking.

The Power Gem mechanic is the signature of this family. These gems deal damage to random enemies each turn and explode for AoE damage when matched. It adds a layer of passive pressure that can finish off low-HP enemies or soften them up for Vander's grenades.

Troop Mastery is excellent for stackers. Dealing 100% extra elemental damage with troops against Holy enemies makes Vander destroy yellow tanks with tile damage alone. The damage reduction from the stronger element (Holy) also helps his survivability against the very heroes he is meant to counter.

Ailment Immunity for the first 6 turns is incredible. It protects him from defense down, silence, mana stop, and mindless attack right at the start of the match. This ensures he can fire his first shot uninterrupted, which is often all you need to gain momentum.

Upon release, Vander was seen as a strong, fun utility hero. He wasn't necessarily "game-breaking" in the way some Goblins or Cartoon heroes were, but his high damage ceiling and silence utility made him a desirable pull.

The damage percentage (450%) is starting to look a bit standard compared to the 500-600% we see on newer snipers. However, the condition to hit 3 enemies keeps him relevant. The main issue is his stat line, which makes him squishier than current meta heroes.

. He is no longer a top-tier defense hero due to his stats, but on offense, he is a fantastic tool. His ability to silence key threats is timeless. He shines in wars against yellow tanks or in bloody battle tournaments where shutting down attackers is key. He is a "Use with Care" hero in high-level play.

As a Wizard, Vander has access to the Jinx talent (chance to deal extra damage). Given his role as a damage dealer and silencer, you want him to hit as hard as possible to ensure that whoever he silences is also severely damaged or dead.
Maximizes the 450% damage multiplier. Makes tile damage significantly higher, leveraging the Troop Mastery passive.
Lower HP makes him vulnerable to modern snipers who might one-shot him.
Keeps him alive longer to utilize his Ailment Immunity and fire his skill multiple times.
Reduces his kill pressure. A 450% hit off a lower attack stat might not penetrate modern defenses effectively.
path is recommended. Vander's defense is already outdated; adding bulk won't save him from a 1500 damage sniper hit, but adding attack might let him kill the enemy before they fire.
Fast Silence is one of the best status ailments in the game.
The potential to hit 3 enemies for massive damage is a huge upside that rewards skilled board play.
Troop Mastery makes his tiles hit incredibly hard against Holy targets.
Ailment Immunity Aether Power guarantees he functions in the opening turns.
His stats are noticeably behind the late 2025 curve.
Sometimes you just don't have 6 purple tiles, leaving you with a single-target hit when you desperately needed a multi-hit.
To maximize his potential, you need to "save" tiles, which can be risky if it means delaying a match.
He excels here. You can control the board to try and set up the 6-tile condition.
Silence is king when healing is disabled, preventing enemies from dealing damage.
Specifically against Holy tanks or flanks.
High tile damage via passives and decent special damage make him usable, though not a specialist.
Vander works best in stacks. Running him 3-2 or Mono-Dark increases the likelihood of having Dark tiles on the board, fueling his conditional skill and his Troop Mastery.
A heavy hitting purple stack. Narcisa resets cooldowns, Vander silences, and Gestalt brings the pain.
Layering mana control. Vander silences, while Proteus/Hel stops mana gain. The enemy never casts a skill.
Heroes who can resist status ailments can shrug off his Silence.
If a Taunt hero activates, Vander can only target them (and potentially nearby if 6 tiles), limiting his reach.
The high resistance of Toon heroes makes landing the Silence unreliable.

If you pulled Vander, celebrate! He is an excellent carry hero. Focus on getting him to 80 and emblem him for attack. Learn to count your tiles; sometimes waiting one turn to get a 6th purple tile on the board is worth it to triple your damage output.

Vander is a luxury tool for your war bench. He likely won't make your primary defense team due to his stats, and he might struggle against top 100 defenses with massive overheals and damage reduction. However, against specific annoying passive teams, his Silence is invaluable. Think twice before using Alpha Aethers; while the immunity is great, you might want to save those for a hero with more modern stats unless you use him daily.
The community reaction to Vander has been generally positive, focusing on his "fun" factor.
"Vander is a fun fellow... I see rarely the 12 more dark shields on the board... but six or more might still happen with some better frequency."
Another pointed out the synergy with the meta:
"He is going to be a menace with a > 50% chance to silence and massive damage to 3."
There's a consensus that while the 12-tile dream is rare, the 6-tile reality is strong:
"Don't be misled and think that that's what you're really getting... you are getting one and a good amount of the time three which is still good."
"Looks like a beast. Will be tough on defense if you are stacking yellow against it and all the purple tiles are left over."

Vander is a cowboy who brings a gun (and grenades) to a knife fight. He offers a blend of high damage and crucial control that remains useful even as his stats age. While he requires a bit of board finesse to unlock his full potential, the payoff of silencing half the enemy team at Fast speed is worth the effort. He might not be the shiny new toy with 3000 HP, but he gets the job done.
A strong offensive weapon that rewards strategic play. Worth leveling for war depth and tournament use, but be mindful of his aging durability.
This analysis is based on the hero's performance as of late 2025, considering the extensive power creep that has occurred since his release.
